awd_titl_txt: Combinatorics of Interacting Particles and Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
The proposed project explores structures that lie at the intersection of combinatorics, representation theory, statistical physics, and integrable systems. The proposed research also has many applications: the key object of this work, the asymmetric simple exclusion process (ASEP), has been studied as a model for traffic flow, as well as in biological processes such as translation in protein synthesis and kinetic biopolymerization. In the longer term, the proposed project has the potential to have an important impact on these applications. Some of the topics of the proposed project are accessible to younger researchers, with several projects intended for work with students. Workshop organization, outreach, and activities aimed at improving climate in STEM are also planned. This project is jointly funded by the Combinatorics program and the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR).


The principal goal of this project is to study the remarkable connection between particle models such as ASEP and orthogonal polynomials. The first part of this work concerns Macdonald polynomials of type A as an application of the combinatorics of the ASEP on a circle, through recently discovered formulas that use multiline queues to connect probabilities of the ASEP to symmetric and nonsymmetric Macdonald polynomials. It is proposed to use those new formulas to explore Schur positivity of modified Macdonald polynomials: one line of attack is to study the quasisymmetric Macdonald polynomial. The second part of this project concerns the extension of the results obtained for Macdonald polynomials of type A to the type BC setting to discover formulas both for Koornwinder polynomials and probabilities of the multispecies ASEP with open boundaries. Thus far such formulas exist only for the two-species ASEP case corresponding to a special case of Koornwinder polynomials, studied in earlier works. It is proposed to merge those results with the multiline queue approach to find a new object that incorporates boundary conditions and admits any number of species.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The theory of interacting particle systems has found rich connections to orthogonal polynomials, symmetric functions, and various combinatorial structures. The aim of the project was to further the study of these connections. We outline some of the objectives achieved. 

The asymmetric simple exclusion process (ASEP) is a non-equilibrium particle model that has applications in modeling traffic, protein synthesis, and other transport processes. The ASEP is deeply linked with classes of symmetric functions called Macdonald polynomials, which are a rich family of polynomials at the forefront of much current research in algebraic combinatorics. Understanding the underlying combinatorial structures of the associated particle models is a powerful tool for studying these polynomials. To this end, the PI, Corteel, Haglund, Mason, and Williams found compact formulas for classical and modified Macdonald polynomials in ``Compact formulas for Macdonald polynomials and quasisymmetric Macdonald polynomials" (published in Selecta). The also introduced quasisymmetric Macdonald polynomials which naturally arise through the connection with the dynamics of particle models, and specialize to the quasisymmetric Schur functions. The PI, Corteel, and Roberts further studied properties of the latter in "Expanding the quasisymmetric Macdonald polynomial in the fundamental basis" (published in Algebraic Combinatorics).

The PI, Ayyer, and Martin discovered a previously unknown connection of the totally asymmetric zero range process (TAZRP) to the modified Macdonald polynomials. Along the way, they proved a new tableau formula for the modified Macdonald polynomials in "Modified Macdonald polynomials and the multispecies zero range process: I" (published in Algebraic Combinatorics). They showed that the nonsymmetric components of this formula specialize to the stationary probabilities of the TAZRP in "Modified Macdonald polynomials and the multispecies zero range process: I" (submitted preprint). 

The PI found a new compact formula for the Macdonald polynomials, accomplishing several goals: it naturally incorporates the dynamics of the ASEP, its nonsymmetric components are the ASEP polynomials that specialize to the probabilities of the ASEP, and it directly maps the plethysm transforming the classical Macdonald polynomial into the modified one to fusion which sends the ASEP to the TAZRP. The formula was conjectured in "New formulas for Macdonald polynomials via the multispecies exclusion and zero range processes," which was written for publication by the AMS in the Contemporary Mathematics (CONM) book series. It was subsequently proved in "A compact formula for the symmetric Macdonald polynomials" (submitted preprint).

The PI, Corteel, and Williams gave a combinatorial formula for the class of Koornwinder polynomials (Macdonald type BC) in "Rhombic staircase tableaux and Koornwinder polynomials" (submitted preprint). Their formula decomposes into nonsymmetric components, which they called the ``open boundary ASEP polynomials''. This result was a first step towards finding a formula for general Koornwinder polynomials through the connection to the ASEP with open boundaries.

Recently, the PI and Valencia-Porras studied the q-Whittacker and Hall-Littlewood specializations of the multiline queue formulas for Macdonald polynomials discovered by the PI and collaborators. They found a charge statistic and a procedure resembling the Robinson-Schensted-Knuth correpondence on multiline queues that naturally recovers several classical results from symmetric function theory. They have a paper "Charge formulas for Macdonald polynomials at t=0 via multiline queues" in final stages of completion.

Over the grant period, extended abstracts for five of the papers mentioned above were accepted as talks (2 papers) and posters (3 papers) at the Formal Power Series and Algebraic Combinatorics conference, a premier yearly conference in algebraic combinatorics. 

The PI is currently supervising two PhD students at the University of Waterloo: Kartik Singh and Jeronimo Valencia-Porras, and one Masters student: William Chan. The PI also supervised a student, Maria Esipova, in an undergraduate research project.


Last Modified: 03/01/2024
Modified by: Olya Mandelshtam
